The patient recently underwent transoral tumor resection surgery. During the postoperative period, there was significant diffuse bleeding in multiple areas, prompting the need for reopening the cutaneous and subcutaneous sutures to manage the hemorrhage. Hemostasis was eventually achieved using bipolar coagulation, ligation of a small vascular stump, and irrigation with Ringer's solution and H2O2. Intraoperatively, the patient received 7 ampoules of Minirin, 1 platelet concentrate, and 1000 mg of tranexamic acid. The surgery concluded with a Redon drain insertion and closure of the surgical site. The patient was transferred intubated and ventilated to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further monitoring and management, with instructions for continued administration of tranexamic acid, Minirin, and follow-up lab checks to assess platelet function and coagulation status.
